results.title: How fair is the jury system?
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, George Cass and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: An audience of students questions a prominent barrister on the fairness of the jury system. The program considers such issues as choosing a jury, eligibility of jurors and alternatives or reforms of the jury sustem.

results.title: How electricity is produced
results.creator_credit: Thomas Stanton, Pat Dowling and Pat Dowling Pictures
results.brief_description: Explains the three ways in which electricity is produced. Depicts Faraday discovering the principle of an induced current, and demonstrates with a small magneto-generator the principle of current electricity.

results.title: How do you drive?
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais, Walford Hewitson and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Released for general use as a public service by the Royal Canadian Air Force, this film demonstrates driving skills as taught at a National Defence Driving School. It follows the course of instruction of a new driver, and shows basic rules for handling a car under a variety of conditions, from turning a corner to halting a skid on ice.

results.title: How did she do it? A literary enquiry into the worldwide appeal of Agatha Christie
results.creator_credit: Toby Wallis, Stephen Hearst and Orsino Productions
results.brief_description: Structured as a mystery novel in itself, this documentary presented by Agatha Christie biographer, Janet Morgan, attempts to unravel the appeal and inspiration behind the Queen of crime. The program includes interviews with fellow crime writer P.D. James (who is not necessarily a big fan of the writer but can appreciate the “fairy tale” aspect to the work), editors, performers, critics and an international vox pop. The program looks at the tenets of Christie’s novels and provides solid biographical details to ascertain why she was compelled to write what she did so prolifically. Narrated by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: How behavior grows
results.creator_credit: Arnold Gesell and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Documentary on the study of the patterning of prone pregression. This study which took 20 years in 23 phases focuses on the progress of a baby’s movements up to 18 months old.

results.title: How atoms combine [B&W]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Introducing Chemistry”.
Three basic types of atomic bonding are clearly and simply illustrated: covalent bonding in which there is an equal sharing of electrons by two or more atoms; polar covalent bonding in which one atom has a greater share than the others; and ionic bonding in which one atom seems to take nearly full control of the electrons from the other atom or radical.

results.title: How animals eat
results.brief_description: This film explains the concept of how animals are equipped for food-getting in order to survive. Teeth, claws, beak, poison mechanisms, web, and other means are studied.

results.title: How about you?
results.brief_description: A sex eductional film which uses a factual but informal style. Discusses social attitudes towards sexuality and shows the effectiveness of a variety of contraceptive methods (somewhat out of date!). It also discusses women’s issues and the freedom of women to own and control their own body. Please note this film was made in 1972 and pre-dates AIDS.

results.title: How a Child Grows (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This documentary follows a baby for the first five days of her life in a Sydney hospital. We see the various tests and examinations that the baby undergoes. The medical staff discuss the main concerns of the parents in these first important days: feeding, jaundice and any behaviour by the baby that doesn’t seem absolutely “normal” to the parents. The mother describes her feelings and reactions during these first emotional days with her new baby.
